instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - does not work with original MagSafe 2
threads.message:
Logic is perfect, no oxidation. The Mac works, but does not charge the battery with original magsafe.

I changed the working DC, removed it from another Mac to test. I changed the <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> (new) twice.

I checked and the <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR>/11, 7151/52, 7121/22 are OK.

PPDCIN is at 3v.

Any tips?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - does not work with original MagSafe 2
threads.message:
What about D/<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>?

Post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> basic voltages, with fake charger, or lab PSU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - does not work with original MagSafe 2
threads.message:
I'm an idiot. The problem was <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>, I was fooled by the protection, it was underneath.

Once again, thank you very much for your help.
